Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Optimal Power Allocation and Relay Selection with Spatial Diversity in Wireless Relay Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: In wireless networks it is critical that power consumption by the communication system is minimized. This calls for new exploratory approaches which incorporate coding, power minimization, and transmission techniques integrated in a system design beyond the current methods. Wireless relay networks in the context of cooperative communications provide favorable platform to address this challenge. Cooperative communications is regarded as one of the few enabling physical layer technologies for wireless networking. By employing relays for joint power and location optimization in cooperative communications, the potential benefits are substantially enhanced. The goal of this proposal is to investigate a mixed-integer nonlinear program (MINLP) which is NP hard, in the formulation and solution of the problem of joint power allocation, relay location, and extended to coding. Lower energy consumption is achieved due to smaller distances between relays and the terminals, spatial diversity, and efficient signal processing schemes such as distributed beam-forming and distributed space time coding. The near optimal solution is found using the combinatorial problem under several relaying architectures. The following cases are investigated: 1) BS-only architecture, 2) single relay per MS, 3) multiple relays per MS, 4) distributed beam-forming, and 5) distributed space-time coding. This project also develops interdisciplinary educational material and courses on wireless communications with the goal of bridging the gap between networking and wireless communications curricula via new interdisciplinary courses. Undergraduate and graduate students will be involved with components of the project that are applicable to their level of interest and ability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In order to maximize throughput and extend the spectrum utiliztion, wireless relays are proposed. For the analysis, D2D models can be extended and enhanced for the pecularities of the wireless relays. In this context the role of SISO and MIMO transmission techniques has been analyzed which also can be extended to the relays. For example, initially, it was of interest to consider operation in multiple modes of D2D. For the purpose of wireless relay studies model formulation was completed, and later techniques of game theory was applied as an economics model for spectrum selection. Subsequently, since the case of intra-cell D2D models of game theory were already considered, we focused on the inter-cell models with interactive decision making process. The utility function is defined as the achievable data rate. The incorporation of inter-cell case requires considering interference from other cells. The additional contribution of the study was consideration of the shared spectrum in the multiple cell case. For example, when two user equioments UE1 and UE 2 are proximal but scattered in the overlaping area of multiple cells, they should be capable of establishing a direct link as long as they are sharing the common spectrum. This was the primary observation for investigating the applicability of game theory to wireless relay (as well as D2D) in this project.

During the project, courses on detection, and estimation as well as wireless communications were developed and offered at SDSM&T. A number of graduate students and post doctroal fellows were also supported.
